title: 115_hr1057
content: The Act may be cited as the "Synthetics Trafficking and Overdose Prevention Act of 2017" or the "STOP Act of 2017." Formal entry requirements for the Postal Service as consignee are outlined. The Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to specify that required documentation for merchandise entry must be filed by the owner, purchaser, or a licensed person. The Postmaster General is designated as the consignee for merchandise imported through the mail. The Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to require that documentation for merchandise entry must be filed by the owner, purchaser, or a licensed person under section 641. U.S. Customs and Border Protection may accept the declaration of ownership by a consignee without liability. The importer of record must be eligible to file the necessary documentation. SEC. 3. INFORMAL ENTRIES. Section 498 of the Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include provisions regarding postal shipments, defining "document" and "merchandise" for the purpose of this subsection. The Postmaster General must comply with entry requirements for merchandise meeting specific criteria, applying identical procedures for merchandise imported through the mail as for merchandise imported via a private carrier. The Postmaster General is authorized to act as the consignee for imported articles that qualify for exemption under certain criteria. They may enter such merchandise using reasonable care. Additionally, customs fees are addressed in the following section. The Postmaster General can act as the consignee for imported articles that meet exemption criteria and enter them with reasonable care. Customs fees for merchandise valued at $2,000 or less arriving at international mail facilities are set at $1 per individual airway bill or bill of lading, or the fee provided for in paragraph (9) if the merchandise is formally entered. The Postmaster General is required to make quarterly payments to U.S. Customs and Border Protection for processing individual airway bills or bills of lading and providing services at international mail facilities. The payments cover expenses for office space, equipment, furnishings, supplies, and security as required by the agency. The Postmaster General is required to make quarterly payments to U.S. Customs and Border Protection for processing individual airway bills or bills of lading and providing services at international mail facilities. 50 percent of the payments received shall be deposited in the Customs User Fee Account to reimburse appropriations for costs incurred in providing services to international mail facilities. The remaining 50 percent will be available for the provision of customs services to international mail facilities. The Postmaster General is required to make quarterly payments to U.S. Customs and Border Protection for processing individual airway bills or bills of lading at international mail facilities. 50 percent of the payments received shall be paid to the Secretary of the Treasury in lieu of fees under paragraph (10). Technical amendments are made to section 13031(a) of the Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985. SEC. 6. MANDATORY ADVANCED ELECTRONIC INFORMATION FOR POSTAL SHIPMENTS. The Trade Act of 2002 is amended to require the Postmaster General to transmit necessary information to U.S. Customs and Border Protection for all shipments by the United States Postal Service, including those received from foreign postal operators. Regulations must impose the same information requirements on both the United States Postal Service and private carriers. SEC. 7. Manifest penalties for the United States Postal Service. Penalties for violations of arrival, reporting, entry, and clearance requirements under the Tariff Act of 1930 are amended to include civil penalties for postal shipments caused by foreign postal operators or the United States Postal Service. Additionally, the Postmaster General may be held responsible for discrepancies in manifests under certain circumstances. The amendment includes civil penalties for postal shipments caused by foreign postal operators or the United States Postal Service due to discrepancies in manifests. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON INTERNATIONAL POSTAL ARRANGEMENTS. The Secretary of State must amend any provisions in agreements violating U.S. obligations under the Universal Postal Union. No delays in implementing this Act are allowed. Future international postal arrangements must align with this Act. SEC. 9. APPLICATION OF OTHER CUSTOMS LAWS. SEC. 9. U.S. Customs and Border Protection to apply import procedures to all merchandise imported through the mail. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue regulations to ensure compliance with Federal law. SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE; REGULATIONS. This Act will be effective upon enactment. The Secretary must establish all necessary regulations within one year of enactment.
